What do you do?

scenes.alt1_feedback: The meeting went very well. Anna and Athena debated whose option made the most sense to proceed with. After one hour, they had come to agree that Athena's suggestion was actually more reasonable. You trust their decision and proceed accordingly.

scenes.name: Resolving Different Approaches
scenes.narrative: Anna sends you and the team her business analysis. She also makes a recommendation for profit goals and budgeting which goes above and beyond what you had expressed. You get an email from another team member, Athena, expressing doubts about the reasonableness of what Anna suggested and providing her own compelling suggestions. Both suggestions seem reasonable, and you are not sure which one is best. How do you react?

scenes.alt1_feedback: Athena shrugged and said that while she still believes her budget and profit goal recommendations are closer to the mark, the rest of the group seems to agree with Anna. She trusts the group's opinion, so she backed down and suggests you move forward with Anna's suggestion. You do so.
scenes.alt1_narrative: Approach Athena after the meeting to ask if she changed her mind or if her prior remarks still stand.
scenes.alt2_feedback: After some hesitation, Athena lays out her point of view. People start leaning in, contributing, and debating - much more than they had before. By the end of the meeting, the team comes to an agreement around an amended version of Athena's suggestion. You trust your team's recommendation and move forward with it.
scenes.alt2_narrative: Tactfully call upon Athena to voice her opinions about the business results.

He is a 'super fan' of Empire Builders and is personally invested in the success of the game. His research shows that when companies offer a discounted bundle of an original game plus an expansion pack, they drive 16% more revenue, on average, than with releases that do not include discounted bundles. This lift in revenue also comes with negligible impact to expenses. You consult your team, and they confirm these findings are reliable. How do you respond?

scenes.name: Supplier Choice
scenes.narrative:
You have received the following emails from two different suppliers. Which do you choose to proceed with?

Good afternoon,

Thank you for reaching out last week. In short, the production and logistics associated with the delivery of the necessary materials to your team will be proportional to the size reduction of the product. From the specs you sent, it seems this product requires 40% of the material that the original Empire Builders requires, so we will reduce our prices to match that drop. Since we've been producing the original units for you over the past 5 years, our processes have gotten significantly more efficient and reliable - we will offer a discount if we receive a large enough initial order. We can chat more over the phone later this week, when works best for you?

-Rick
Hey there,

Thanks for dropping me an email! Please see our attached proposal. In summary: We would love to work with you and are more than happy to offer a handsome discount if it means we get to kick off a long happy partnership! We absolutely don't want to miss the opportunity to work with Yayco on their big new release.
We recognize that you have a long-standing relationship with one of our competitors, and we totally understand how difficult it can be to shake off old ways of doing things. Therefore, we will gladly provide any sort of informal incentive needed to get the ball rolling on this. We can also guarantee to beat any competitor's price by 10%! Let's set up a time to discuss what you'd need to make the decision easier for you!

-Jess

scenes.alt1_narrative:

scenes.name: Distribution Issues
scenes.narrative: The expansion pack is flying off the shelves - you are unable to restock them fast enough. Your head of Distribution tells you that one of the biggest bottlenecks comes from distributers being directed to reach out to the Yayco Distributer Center, not directly to the Empire Builders Distribution Team. Restocking shelves would be faster if this redundant intermediary step were removed from this process; however, your team doesn't know what they can do about it. As far as you can tell, the original purpose of this system was to make the lives of product distribution team members easier by assisting in triage, but in moments like this it becomes a huge bottleneck. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative: Pull the team together, tell them that the board is very happy with the expansion pack's performance, and use the discretionary funds to award every team member a $200 gift card.
scenes.alt2_narrative: Send the team an email quoting the great things the chairman said about them and thank them for the amazing job they have done. Let them suggest and vote on ideas for a team activity to celebrate a job well done.
scenes.alt3_narrative: Surprise the team with an extravagant dinner and night out in the city! Congratulate them on a job well done.
scenes.name: Celebrate Success

scenes.name: Redirect Expansion Pack Design
scenes.narrative: Your testing revealed that participants were initially confused by the term "expansion pack". Some focus group participants interpreted the term the way you intended - a different, stand-alone, larger version of Empire Builders. Your team has called this the "stand-alone" version of the expansion pack. However, a large percentage of focus group participants understood the term "expansion pack" to be an add-on that would augment their current Empire Builders board game, literally expanding or changing it. So far, your team has been focused on the initial, "stand-alone" expansion pack. Anecdotally, however, focus group participants seem just as interested in the second "add-on" option. This is partly due to many focus group participants already having Empire Builders at home. What do you do?

scenes.name: The Prismz Challenge
scenes.narrative: Users of the product have noticed an interesting characteristic that even your team had not realized. The new inert plastic seems to be incredibly resistant to heat, to such a degree that it seems to be "fire proof." What started as a single video, which made note of how Prismz won't melt under almost any circumstances, has turned into a viral craze. Prismz' fire resistance has become a meme to such a degree that people are creating content around what is being called "The Prismz Challenge" to show off different creative ways to leverage this. It all started off relatively innocuously, but it has quickly escalated to things as extreme as people standing on a platform made of Prismz while a fire burns directly under them. How do you respond?

scenes.name: Assignment for a Trustworthy Team Member
scenes.narrative: Sandra, one of your most trustworthy analysts, oversees running the business analysis for this project. She comes to your office and hands you the report in person. Immediately, you notice she isn't her normal, chipper self, so you ask if something is wrong. She tells you that the report was ready to go yesterday, but her supervisor, Moira, who is another very experienced analyst, disagreed with some of her projections and asked her to rerun her analysis with different assumptions. You can tell she doesn't feel that this report represents her point of view. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_feedback: Sandra comes into your office later that week and drops the business analysis on your desk without a word. It was nearly identical to the version that she first handed you. You move forward with their suggestions.
scenes.alt1_narrative: Speak to them individually. Communicate your disappointment in how the meeting ran, and give them feedback on what they each need to improve upon. Task them to work together on pulling together a report they both agree on by the end of the week.
scenes.alt2_feedback: Through digging deeper, you found that the reason underlying Moira's behavior was a feeling of betrayal. Moira felt that Sandra had portrayed her to you as being an incompetent micromanager, so she felt the need to assert herself. She begrudgingly admitted that, upon second review, Sandra's analysis was better than her own. You coach Moira on how she can mend her relationship with Sandra, and she commits to doing so. You move forward with Sandra's suggestion.
scenes.alt2_narrative: Speak with Moira. Ask her probing questions about why she would not discuss the analysis with Sandra. Use this as a coaching opportunity.
scenes.alt3_feedback: Sandra appreciated your help with formulating her thoughts, and the following week she dropped the business analysis on your desk without a word. When you asked how it went, she just shrugged. You opened the report and found that it was nearly identical to the first version of the report she handed you. You move forward with their suggestions.
scenes.alt3_narrative: Challenge Sandra. Her communication with her supervisor was suboptimal, so you coach her to better articulate her thoughts. Instruct her to set a meeting with Moira to try again once the dust settles.
scenes.name: Encouraging Point of View in Meetings
scenes.narrative: You pulled Sandra and Moira into a meeting to discuss the business analysis. What followed would be better characterized as an argument, not a constructive debate. Moira repeatedly shut down Sandra, dismissing her point of view as being unrealistic. You tried your best to facilitate the discussion, but Moira was not persuaded at all by Sandra's points, causing Sandra to raise her voice. By the end of the meeting, an apathetic Moira had swiveled her chair around to face away from Sandra, who stood with arms crossed, fuming and confused. The meeting ended with nothing accomplished. What do you do?

Low

scenes.name: Budgeting the Game
scenes.narrative: You've delegated finding the optimal profit goal and budgeting to one of your direct reports. He came to you asking about Web servers and how you want to manage the Web traffic for Battle of Planes. Admittedly, you do not know much about this area, whereas he has spent 10+ years in this space. You are accountable for the outcome of these projections and budgeting.  What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Pay once upfront in the app store.
Pros
  • A fixed, guaranteed revenue per download
Cons
  • Barriers to entry
  • Not a common form of monetization
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Free to play, with microtransactions throughout the game, which will allow users to level up and attain items faster.
Pros
  • No barrier to entry
  • Players are incentivized to purchases in-game to make the experience more fun
Cons
  • No guaranteed revenue per download
  • Viewed as a controversial business model
  • Lower retention rates
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Free to play, with microtransactions purely for aesthetics.
Pros
  • No barrier to entry
  • Widely accepted as the most palatable monetization scheme by users
Cons
  • No guaranteed revenue per download
  • Little incentive to make in-app purchases
scenes.alt4_narrative:
Pay upfront in the app store + microtransactions throughout the game, which will allow users to level up and attain items faster.
Pros
  • A fixed, guaranteed revenue per download
  • Players are incentivized to make purchases in-game to make the experience more fun
  • The most revenue generated per download of all four business models
Cons
  • Lower retention rates
  • Viewed as a controversial business model
  • Barrier to entry
scenes.name: Business Model Decision
scenes.narrative: An important consideration is the business model that this game will utilize. There are multiple business models in this app/game space. Your team approaches you with the four most feasible options and asks for your direction about how to proceed. Seeing their report below, which do you proceed with?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Give them the time to do their best work and push back the release date to make sure you have a quality product.

Impact on Time to Market: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Pushing back the release date is the absolute last option. You have to get back on track as soon as possible. Ask them to come back to you with suggestions for how to overcome the issue and maintain the scheduled release date

Impact on Time to Market: None

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Instruct them to ignore the red tape and to execute. You will take care of the IT department.

LTU investment: Low

scenes.name: Old Processes Causing Bottlenecks
scenes.narrative: The team comes back to you and reveals that one of the biggest bottlenecks to fixing this issue is getting clearance from the greater internal Yayco IT department every step of the way. This does not seem to serve any practical purpose; rather, it is an outdated process from over a decade ago that remains as a policy today. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:

scenes.name: Managing Alpha Testing Data
scenes.narrative: Alpha game tester data has come back, and users are not spending as much money in-app as forecasted. Your team says this is to be expected and assures you that this is driven largely by the fact that this is a test audience who know that they are receiving an early version of the game and, therefore, are much less likely to buy anything. They share that this is typical of alpha testing across the gaming industry. However, a couple of Yayco leaders have expressed deep concerns about these results, and they are insisting that you need to figure out how to drive more revenue or else the game may lose the company a lot of money. They have even threatened to cut the game if it poses a serious risk of failure. What do you do?

scenes.name: GDPR Guidelines
scenes.narrative: The Yayco Legal team has reached out to you with some bad news. They notify you that, as the product stands, it is questionable whether or not it meets the EU's General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) standards. Had you reached out earlier in the process, they would have been able to warn you. However, they tell you that the product is walking a fine line and that launching it in Europe (one of your leading markets) might put Yayco at risk. Going back and making sure that you meet GDPR guidelines would cost resources and have a seriously negative impact on your time to market. What do you do?

scenes.name: Using Free Software
scenes.narrative: An online advertising network catches wind that Yayco is introducing its first digital product. A representative of this firm reaches out and asks if Yayco is interested in partnering on testing a new product. Their new software can be embedded in the app and, via a front-facing camera, can discern (with 85% accuracy, using their AI algorithm) the emotions of users as they use your application. They say this will provide you with insights to help make your user experience "stickier." This service would be provided free of charge, but as part of this partnership, they would like to receive some of this data for their own commercial use. They assure you that no Personally Identifying Information (PII) will be compromised, nor will any videos or pictures be stored. While the software is in line with the privacy policy, users don't easily understand that their data may be shared with third parties. How do you proceed?

scenes.alt1_narrative: Be transparent. Release a statement describing the type of attack and explaining how they could not and do not have access to the user information they speak of. Assure the public that the game is entirely safe, that no user information has been leaked, and that this type of cyber-attack is comparable to a traffic jam. Do not engage with the hacker.
scenes.alt2_narrative: Keep it in-house. Do not release a statement. Secure your servers, and do not engage with the hacker. Make sure you are prepared for the next time it happens.
scenes.name: Server Crash
scenes.narrative: The release of the product has been going very smoothly when you suddenly experience a server crash. Your team informs you that it's not a typical crash, but rather a DDoS cyber-attack that is crashing your servers. Not only that, but the hacker responsible for the attack has reached out and threatened to release user information if you do not pay a ransom. The YayCo team assures you they have run a system check, and that there is no way the hacker has any user information - it is a bluff, they say. The servers are now back under YayCo's control. How do you handle this situation?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Thank him for the great idea and the time he took on this. You tell him that you are not sure it is a top priority at the moment, but that you would love to integrate it once things slow down. Promise that you will revisit this a few months after launch.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Thank him for his time and have him reach out to a few necessary stakeholders to set up a meeting. Bringing them together will help you understand what is needed to bring this idea to fruition.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Spend some time exploring the idea on your own with SMEs across Yayco.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.name: Junior Team Brings New Idea
scenes.narrative:
One of your most junior developers nervously asked to speak with you for half an hour. He tells you he wanted to set up this quick meeting to talk with you about a concept he has for the next update of the game. He introduced the idea of adding a health tracking element to the game. Players already spend so much time outside walking around, why not reward them for meeting the daily recommended health standards for steps to be taken in a day? Players could then unlock special items if they meet or exceed their daily goals. You can even integrate other health metrics, such as heart rate, if players have a smart wearable. He also introduced the idea of rewarding group play, so that players will be encouraged to meet up and socialize with their friends in real life as they work together to level up and play through the game as a party.

He even wrote up a report for both the development timeline, and what resources would be necessary to make this a reality. You think it's a great idea, but it will be a resource-intensive project to undertake. What do you do?

scenes.PrivacyDesc:
Please review the Consent Agreement and Privacy Policies below.

Consent Agreement

To meet our responsibility to you and PepsiCo, who requested that you participate in this 3DM (Data Driven Decision Making) simulation, we want to share with you what happens to your simulation results.

BTS may collect this data, use it for research and product improvement purposes, and disclose it to PepsiCo. All information collected in this simulation will be handled in accordance to PepsiCo's Global Privacy Policy, PepsiCo's GDPR Supplement and BTS's Privacy Policy.

PepsiCo Privacy Policy
PepsiCo GDPR Supplement
BTS Privacy Policy

By clicking "I Agree", you consent to participate in The PepsiCo 3DM Simulation and agree to these policies.
scenes.PrivacyInstruction: BEFORE YOU BEGIN, PLEASE CAREFULLY REVIEW THE FOLLOWING:
scenes.Product1Info:
Empire Builders, a classic strategy board game created in Austria in the mid-1990s, was acquired by YayCo in the mid-2000s. It had underwhelming acceptance for its first few years on the market. However, sales slowly rose after its rough kickoff and around 2009 there was a sudden shift in consumer sentiment toward board games. Seemingly overnight, Empire Builders became an instant classic, the face of a global renaissance in board games. YayCo rode the wave of popularity through most of the 2010s, but the past few years have brought a decrease in sales. YayCo wants to breathe new life into this game, and to do so, leadership has brought you onboard to develop and release a long-awaited and much-requested expansion pack.


Concurrent to this initiative, YayCo recently acquired a small game design firm named Senko. The purpose of the acquisition was two-fold. First, Senko has significant, valuable IP that YayCo believes it can leverage in upcoming and current products. Second, and most relevant to this project, Senko is known for its high-quality games and talented designers. Four senior members from Senko are now your direct reports, and you feel they will be instrumental in crafting a strategy for the board game expansion you are planning.
scenes.Product2Info:
Prismz was the first toy developed by YayCo in the 1970s, and it continues to be the company's most recognizable and successful product. Prismz is a line of plastic construction toys based around colorful interlocking bricks that has since expanded to include a variety of different parts, such as small figurines and gears. The product has seen great success since the 1980s, and it continues to stay relevant with its target audience, children, even to this day.


In recent years, a growing public interest in environmental issues has brought a drastic shift away from plastics. The toy industry has been under particular scrutiny, as there have been multiple reports of discarded plastic products having a negative impact on marine life. YayCo has faced issues surrounding how its products may react negatively to salt water, releasing harmful chemicals that can interfere with photosynthesis and harm wildlife, (e.g., affecting kelp and some corals). As a company that prides itself on its sustainability efforts, YayCo wants to take immediate action by transitioning its Prismz products to an eco-friendly material.
scenes.Product3Info: Though currently little more than a rough idea, Battle of Planes will be an augmented reality game in which players interact with the world around them through their smartphones. They will be able to collect items and battle other players' airplanes, all while walking around their neighborhoods. Battle of Planes represents completely new territory for YayCo. One of the main reasons YayCo acquired Senko was because of Senko's advanced capabilities in the augmented reality space. They are best known for their partnership with Nintendies on the wildly successful game PikimenGo! Though there are many avenues that YayCo plans to pursue while leveraging Senko's technology capabilities, leadership wants to test the waters and treat Battle of Planes as a spin-off based heavily on the world of Empire Builders.

scenes.Title: Leader Day
scenes.VisionStatementContent: Welcome to YayCo, one of the most recognizable names in the world of toys and board games. YayCo has been a major industry leader in this space for forty years, but with major cultural and economic shifts threatening their position in the market place, YayCo leadership has decided it is time for change.  The company is in the midst of several major strategic shifts in an effort to keep up with changing consumer demand. As part of these strategic pivots, YayCo has turned to you to manage the development and repositioning of the three products at the center of the company's revamp. To further support these pivots, YayCo has recently acquired a small game design firm named Senko.
scenes.VisionStatementEmail:
You are about to start the PepsiCo 3DM (Data Driven Decision Making) Assessment and we want to tell you three things before you start:

1) Our CEO finds this to be a top priority:

"At PepsiCo, our vision is to be the global leader in convenient foods and beverages by winning with purpose. It is a bold, ambitious goal that we can only achieve by working together as One PepsiCo. So, over the past several months, we have developed a single approach to culture that is meant to empower us to achieve our vision.

We call this The PepsiCo Way.

Our culture is our greatest strength. It is what enables us to attract the best talent and empowers each associate with a winning spirit. Every associate has a role to play in helping to inform how The PepsiCo Way will shape our culture, both locally and globally. I know we will become faster, stronger, and better, and continue our journey to be the global leader in convenient foods and beverages by winning with purpose."

-Ramon Laguarta, Chairman and CEO at PepsiCo


2) The PepsiCo Way is at the center of this experience.

You will receive a report shortly after the completion of the simulation. It will provide feedback on how well you have applied the PepsiCo Way during the simulation.


3) There will be a competition between all participants of this experience, just for the fun of it. The competition will be based on the overall business result. Your screen name and your result will be listed on the Leaderboard with the top 50 scorers. A link to the leaderboard will be available once you complete the assessment. But, of course - the PepsiCo Way feedback is still of greater importance.

A few additional hints:
  • The simulation will take one to two hours.
  • You must complete the simulation in one sitting. Please find a time that is free of distraction and a location that has a stable internet connection.
  • You can retake the assessment as many times as you would like.

Have fun and good luck!
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText1: LTU is an acronym for Leadership Time Units - LTUs represent your time. They are a limited resource that will be consumed by completing tasks that require your time and involvement. You may spend more LTUs than you have been allotted; however, dipping into negative LTUs will hurt the business.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText10: Clicking the "i" button to the left of each product will display additional background information about that product.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText11: The "Background" link will open a brief background of YayCo.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText12: The "Welcome Video" link will open re-open the introductory video.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText13: This progress bar illustrates how much of the simulation you have completed.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText14: There may be some decisions to make in the moment - don't be surprised if a decision pops up that you weren't expecting!
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText15:
Your winning metric is computed by evaluating your employee, customer, and consumer satisfaction, along with your revenue, profit, time to market, and LTUs. Keep an eye at the banner at the top of the screen to make sure your decisions are moving you towards winning.

If you run into any technical issues, contact the BTS Help Desk at AssessmentHelpdesk@bts.com, or at 1.800.701.5783 (US & Canada) / 1.718.832.8149 (International). You can expect a response within 24 hours.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText2: There are 5 initiatives that you are given the opportunity to launch. You can choose to move forward with all of them, some of them, or none of them. To reach 100% completion, you must see all initiatives through to their end by either completing them or choosing not to move forward with them.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText3: Insights will become available based on the decisions you make. You can reference the Insights available to you at any time. The Insights button will blink whenever new information is available. As you progress through the decisions, more insights will be available - be sure you check the tabs that will appear under each of the three products.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText4: The metrics in the top banner show YayCo's aggregate business performance across the three products. Please note that the effect of some of your decisions will not be reflected in the metrics until the product hits the market in the Commercialization phase; for example, you will not see any impacts on Revenue until then.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText5: There are decisions you must make for each of the three products you will manage - these decisions will appear here. Some decisions will ask you to pick one answer from many, whereas other decisions will allow you to pick as many selections as you would like.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText6:
Each product will each go through 6 lifecycle stages over the course of the simulation.

The current phase for each product will be displayed here. The phases are:
  • Concept Development and Testing
  • Business Analysis
  • Product Development
  • Test Marketing
  • Commercialization
  • Growth Stage
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText7: Each product has its own set of metrics, including revenue, profit, and stakeholder impressions.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText8: Customer satisfaction on the Battle of Planes product is unavailable, as the game is available direct to consumers.
scenes.WalkthroughHighlightText9: Each product also has a time to market - you will be taking each product from its initial concepting phase to market (and beyond).

scenes.name: Carry on with Process Simplification & Digitization Initiative
scenes.narrative: A surprising number of YayCo's processes are paper based and incredibly inefficient. Would you like to carry on with the initiative to invest in the digitization of all paper-based processes across your three product lines?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Be firm in your stance and carry on.

Monetary Cost: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Have one of your directs investigate further to get to the bottom of what is the most likely outcome.

Monetary Cost: None

Halt the initiative.

Monetary Cost: Medium
scenes.name: Process Simplification & Digitization: Correct Timing
scenes.narrative: The morning after announcing the digitization, you receive half a dozen emails from different project leads. All say that undergoing this initiative could negatively impact their timelines, as their teams are not familiar with the new systems that will be introduced. They express that they understand the need for change; however, they say that now is not a good time. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Nothing.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Once all the materials have been scanned, forward this database to YayCo's CIO.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Ask your team to spend extra time to identify any potentially useful concepts or ideas for your current project.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.name: Process Simplification & Digitization: Newfound Information
scenes.narrative: As this digitization has begun, several lost or forgotten designs unexpectedly resurfaced as the Prismz archives were scanned. You've seen a few of these, and you were surprised to find that they were not just designs for Prismz kits, but also designs for manufacturing technologies and packaging. What do you do with this newfound information?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Implement these changes.

Monetary Cost: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Hold onto this for a future date.

Monetary Cost: None
scenes.name: Process Simplification & Digitization: New Molding Process
scenes.narrative: Your team discovers a molding process that will reduce the amount of plastic in your Prismz bricks by 15% without negatively affecting their structural integrity. This would be a huge cost saver for YayCo down the road; however, implementing this across your manufacturing facilities would cost a lot of time and resources in the short term. What you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Yes

scenes.name: Carry on with Diversity & Engagement Initiative
scenes.narrative: YayCo is interested in bringing the best ideas to the table. The company does this not just by employing a diverse set of people with diverse ideas, but also by making sure that they feel they have a space where they can voice their ideas. Would you like to carry on with the initiative to invest in an initiative centered on encouraging diverse hiring practices, inclusion and awareness training, and sensitivity workshops?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Set up a meeting with Raj and hear out his concerns. Show tough love. Coach him through the importance of creating a safe space for others to voice such opinions, and indicate how this serves as a learning opportunity for him to change his conduct.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Speak with the workshop facilitator to see how you can best mitigate people feeling attacked.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.name: Diversity & Engagement: Dealing with Feedback
scenes.narrative: You just received an angry email from one of the more senior members of your team, Raj. During one of the workshops, a central activity was for team members to share a time when they felt they had been excluded. Raj is livid because a story shared by one of the team members was about something that he had done. Though the story was told without revealing any names, Raj felt "humiliated, disrespected, and misrepresented" and he insists that this sort of activity be removed from all future workshops. Raj is typically a calm, laid-back person; you have never seen him this upset about something. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Set up a meeting with Raj and hear out his concerns. Show tough love. Coach him through the importance of creating a safe space for others to voice such opinions, and indicate how this serves as a learning opportunity for him to change his conduct.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:

scenes.alt3_feedback: You decided to dig a bit deeper. You review the post-workshop survey and find that the participant satisfaction scores for the program are very high and nearly all comments left by team members are highly positive. You ask around the office and hear rave reviews about the program. When you ask individuals how the story-sharing portion went, everyone says that it felt like a really liberating experience, that they enjoyed it and found it productive. You tactfully ask a couple of your more trusted senior members if any of the stories were recognizable as something that happened at YayCo or on the team; they answer "no".
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Spend some time looking into this a bit further.

LTU investment: High
scenes.name: Diversity & Engagement: Dealing with Feedback
scenes.narrative: You just received an angry email from one of the more senior members of your team, Raj. During one of the workshops, a central activity was for team members to share a time when they felt they had been excluded. Raj is livid because a story shared by one of the team members was about something that he had done. Though the story was told without revealing any names, Raj felt "humiliated, disrespected, and misrepresented" and he insists that this sort of activity be removed from all future workshops. Raj is typically a calm, laid-back person; you have never seen him this upset about something. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Be patient; do not take any further actions.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Invest time into re-evaluating if any individual contributors might be good candidates for management positions.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.name: Diversity & Engagement: Female Representation
scenes.narrative: As part of this initiative, you asked your teams to fill out a questionnaire about their experience with diversity and inclusion at YayCo. You get the results back, and the findings are surprising. The most resounding takeaway from the questionnaire was that many of the female team members feel that female representation in management positions across your teams is inadequate. When you investigate, you find a 3:7 ratio of females to males in management positions on your team. You already have an initiative underway to put an emphasis on diversity in hiring (including gender diversity). How do you address this?

scenes.alt1_narrative: Pass the final decision off to your head of Sales.
scenes.alt2_narrative: Instruct your head of Sales that it's not a disqualifying characteristic and must be ignored in the hiring decision.
scenes.name: Diversity & Engagement: Tough Hiring Decision
scenes.narrative: There is a candidate in the final-round interview for a sales position on your team. As part of this interview, you are called in to watch the candidate's presentation. The candidate does a fantastic job, is incredibly engaging, and by all accounts is a great candidate for this sales position. After the interview, your head of Sales comes to you and expresses doubts about the candidate's ability to fill this role due to a mobility impairment that requires them to use a wheelchair. How do you respond?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Yes

Monetary Cost:Low

scenes.name: Carry on with Knowledge Sharing Initiative
scenes.narrative: YayCo does not currently have a database in which best practices, product information, resources, etc., can be shared. Would you like to invest in the initiative to implement an online knowledge-sharing platform to improve information flow across your teams?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Focus on your product lines first. Once your team's needs are met, explore how to expand the database to other parts of YayCo.

LTU investment: None
Monetary Cost: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Expand the scope to include other parts of YayCo.

LTU investment: Medium
Monetary Cost: Low
scenes.name: Knowledge Sharing: Increase the Scope
scenes.narrative: Recently two colleagues reached out to you regarding the knowledge-sharing platform that you are developing. Each leads their own respective line of business, and they are very interested in leveraging the platform your team is working on. They immediately dive into different needs that they are hoping this database will address for them. Expanding the scope to address the needs of these other lines of business will push back the completion date of the database by at least 3 months. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Send out a reminder email.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Speak about the database in meetings.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Create an incentive whereby those who submit work into the database are put into a lottery to win a monetary reward.

LTU investment: Medium

scenes.alt5_narrative:
Make adding work to the database a mandatory part of everyone's workflow.

LTU investment: High
scenes.name: Knowledge Sharing: Increasing Usage
scenes.narrative: You and your team are proud of the final product and finally release it by announcing it in a meeting and via email. After a few weeks, you find that usage rates are still very low - only 5% of employees have used the database even once. The project lead tells you that the reason is likely a lack of awareness and a lack of incentive to add to the database. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Yes

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
No

scenes.name: Carry on with Improving Sustainability Initiative
scenes.narrative: Except for the new Prismz development, YayCo has never made any sort of strategic shift based on environmental concerns. Would you like to carry on with the initiative to create a committee that investigates the most tangible and actionable changes that YayCo can make to reduce its footprint on the environment?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Move forward with both initiatives.

LTU investment: High
Monetary Cost: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Move forward with only the internal initiative.

LTU investment: Medium
Monetary Cost: Low

Monetary Cost: Low

Monetary Cost: None
scenes.name: Improving Sustainability: Splitting up the Initiative
scenes.narrative: After two months, the exploratory committee returns with a report outlining their suggestions for the best course of action. Their proposal splits the initiative into two parts: an internal initiative and an external initiative. The internal initiative is focused around modernizing YayCo manufacturing and corporate buildings to be certified as eco-friendly and minimally wasteful. The external initiative is focused mostly on reducing the amount of material used in YayCo packaging. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Renovate around the systems. Come back to this issue at a more convenient time.

LTU investment: None
Monetary Cost: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Push forward with the renovation and remove these systems.

LTU investment: Medium
Monetary Cost: Low
scenes.name: Improving Sustainability: Facilities Fiasco
scenes.narrative: You are told that roughly a third of YayCo's facilities have an antiquated emergency fire extinguishing mechanism that contains toxic chemicals. All of these systems have been cut off from a power source, so they do not pose any danger in their current state. However, removing them is an important part of the renovation process, and each building that has these antiquated systems must be vacated for approximately two weeks during the system's removal. All oudated fire extinguisher systems must eventually be removed, but you are told that this can be done any time in the next ten years. However, the longer you wait, the more difficult it will be since additional infrastructure continues to be built around the systems. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Halt the production and use of the new packaging and revert to your previous packaging methods. Pause, reevaluate, and try again once you are 100% sure you can reenter the market. Release a statement assuring the public that you want to "Get it right" and are committed to your sustainability efforts.

LTU investment: High
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Push forward. Release a statement saying that the problem has been remedied and that you are committed to pushing on with your sustainability efforts.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.name: Improving Sustainability: Packaging Issues
scenes.narrative: You have been notified that there is an issue with the new, more environmentally friendly packaging you are using for your Prismz and Empire Builders products. This new packaging has been on the market for just a couple of weeks. Consumers and customers are very unhappy, reporting that the ink used on the cardboard easily rubs off and can stain hands and clothing. A few news outlets are running this story as "Eco-Friendly Fail." Your materials scientists come to you and assure you that they have located the problem, remedied it, and tested the solution. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Yes

LTU investment: High
Monetary Cost: Low
scenes.alt2_narrative:
No

LTU investment: None
Monetary Cost: None
scenes.name: Carry on with Mentoring Programs Initiative
scenes.narrative: Would you like to carry on with a talent development initiative that offers both formal training to architect growth on teams, as well as a mentoring program to pair employees with a more senior advisor to help them navigate career aspirations?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Suggest that this program might not be right for him, as the pairings are random.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Accommodate his request.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Coach him in how to mentor a younger female.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.name: Mentoring Programs: Difficult Issue
scenes.narrative: The mentoring program is off to a good start, but you were recently approached by a mentor with a difficult issue. This mentor told you that while he very much wants to be a mentor to the younger generations, he does not feel comfortable mentoring younger women because he fears potential misinterpretation of his communication or actions as something inappropriate. He asked to be paired with men only. How do you address this situation?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Own the change by pulling all your managers and directors into a meeting. Apologize for the disconnect caused by your oversight, and explain the new shift in how we are approaching feedback culture. Then have an all-teams meeting in which you reaffirm your commitment to this change and set expectations regarding its continuation.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Send out two emails, one to managers and directors and the other to all your employees. In these messages, outline your expectations for the adoption of this new approach to improve the culture at YayCo.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt3_narrative:
To be transparent about the disconnect and why it happened, send out an email. Encourage teams to continue with candid feedback to whatever extent they agree upon in their own individual project teams.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.name: Mentoring Programs: Unexpected Outcome
scenes.narrative: There has been an unexpected consequence of sending your teams through the formal development programs. The programs are currently split into two groups, individual contributors (ICs) and managers/directors, with each group receiving training from a different company. The problem is that ICs are being taught the importance of candid feedback, while this was not addressed in the curriculum that managers and directors receive, nor was it something they were expecting to start suddently receiving. You've received messages all morning from confused ICs and from upset managers and directors who were not ready for the wave of candid critique. Your team members don't understand what is going on. How do you fix this?

scenes.alt1_narrative: Send out an email to all mentors to clarify what is expected of them and what they cannot do.
scenes.alt2_narrative: Unpair the mentor and mentee. Reach out to the mentor and speak to him about what transpired. Make sure it does not occur again.
scenes.alt3_narrative: Remove the mentor from the mentorship program.
scenes.name: Mentoring Programs: Unexpected Outcome
scenes.narrative: A mentee recently sent you an upsetting email. His mentor had submitted the mentee's CV for a role in another part of the business without his permission. The mentee had expressed interest in the role but never committed to it. Somehow, word got out that the mentee had applied somewhere else, which strained his relationship with his team. He didn't want you to intervene, but he expressed anger that a trusted mentor would overstep to such a degree. How do address this issue?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Proactively go to the employee, express condolences, and remind them that they can take the entire three days and that the team will handle things in their absence.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Do not do anything; see how the employee handles the situation.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Drop by the employee's desk, express condolences, and remind them that their fellow team members are putting in overtime, since it is "crunch time" for the product launches.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.name: Death in Family
scenes.narrative: An immediate family member of one of your senior employees just passed away, and you're in "crunch time" a week before a couple of your large initiatives start. YayCo policy is that if an immediate family member passes, the employee receives 3 days of bereavement leave. How do you handle this situation?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Attend the focus groups.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Respectfully decline but ask for a summary of the meetings to be sent over. Make it clear that you still want to contribute in any way you can.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Respectfully decline.

LTU investment: None
scenes.name: Health Insurance Offering
scenes.narrative: YayCo's CHRO unexpectedly reaches out and asks you to participate in focus groups regarding the new YayCo health insurance offerings. Though it will take about four hours of your time, you are very interested in participating, since it will have a direct impact on you and your team's health insurance offerings for next year. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Gladly take the opportunity.

LTU investment: High
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Politely and regrettably decline.

LTU investment: None
scenes.name: Award Acceptance
scenes.narrative: An article was published recently in Now Magazine about the effect of heteronormativity in children's toys. YayCo was praised as a toymaker with a good history of making products that are gender neutral in nature. YayCo was nominated, and subsequently won, an award for inclusive business practices from The Inclusive Foundation. YayCo's CEO asked if you would like to accept the award in her place, as she feels it will be a good opportunity to show the world YayCo's core values. However, she says that she realizes how last-minute the request is, so not to worry if you are too busy to travel - she can have another leader take her place. Going to this event would be a long ordeal, as it is taking place on the other side of the world.  What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Let it blow over; do not fuel the fire.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Take a moderate approach. Make a public statement condemning these actions and any threats to your employees.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Go public and protect your employees. Make a public statement condemning these actions and any threats to your employees. Explore possible legal action against this individual for inciting violence.

LTU investment: High
scenes.name: Fringe Content Creator
scenes.narrative: A fringe online content creator with a cult following has recently chosen YayCo as the target of a barrage of conspiracy theories. This has mobilized his fringe base, and his base has taken it upon themselves to investigate what YayCo is nefariously hiding. This has led to videos of YayCo employees being harassed and interrogated on their daily commute by some crazed supporters of the online content creator. The YayCo workers in the videos are visibly distressed and bothered by the barrage of questions. The board wants your opinion on how to handle this situation. What's your advice?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Ask her to stay, but promise to support her the next time such a position opens up.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Ask her to stay, but help her expand into business development roles for the products you manage. While this is not exactly what she was after, it will hopefully satisfy her for the time being and prepare her for the next time the role opens up.

LTU investment: Low
scenes.alt3_narrative:
Support her request. Spend time writing a stellar recommendation and make plans for how you will offset her workload if she is accepted.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.name: Direct Report Development
scenes.narrative: One of your highest-performing direct reports, Patricia, comes to you asking if you would support her if she were to pursue a role in a different part of the business. Patricia says she has absolutely loved working with you for the past several years, but she has always wanted to transition to a business development role. The business development position Patricia is aiming for opened up last week. The position opens every year or two. Patricia was hoping you would recommend her for the role. This puts you in a tough spot - Patricia is incredibly talented. You know that she is more than capable of excelling in a business development role, but dividing her workload among her colleagues would be pushing the team's capacity. The deadline for the application is at the end of next week. What do you do?

scenes.alt1_narrative:
Do nothing. Talk with your manager and present the data.

LTU investment: None
scenes.alt2_narrative:
Email the team to set up a strike force to research the situation.

LTU investment: Medium
scenes.name: YayCo Sales
scenes.narrative: A junior team member comes to you and reports that sales for Empire Builders are the lowest they've been in a year and asks what measures YayCo should take to ensure future sales. It's currently May 2020. You hesitate and ask the team member for historical sales data for Empire Builders. He provides the charts. After analyzing this data, what do you do? (All figures are in US dollars)

  • Those who were given a sample of the material notices less flex than with the original version, sparking concerns about tactile experience.
  • There are some concerns about the durability of a biodegradable material.
  • Collectors often see Prismz kits as long-term investments.
  • Biodegradable products do not have a good reputation for long-term durability.
  • Generally positively received. Teens showed a particular affinity for how eco-friendly this version seems.

Additional Information
  • This demographic reports high exposure and affinity for TV marketing campaigns.
  • This demographic responds particularly well to partnerships with popular movies and TV shows.
  • Further questioning revealed that parents are less concerned with the environmental effects of Prismz than they are with the health effects on their children. The recent revelations about the release of toxic chemicals has them more concerned about their children's safety.
  • Members of this demographic do not often play with Prismz; parents predominantly purchase the product as a gift.
  • A common behavior that this demographic exhibits is passing on Prismz from older children to younger children as they grow older.
  • This population is rarely exposed to Prismz marketing. The only time they are exposed is when watching television with their children.
  • Eighty-three percent of parents report that their decision on which kit to buy is informed by what is requested by their child.
  • Members of this demographic express that they will likely purchase regardless of which concept you proceed with.
  • As with children, this audience is exposed to Prismz primarily through TV marketing.
  • It was found that early teens (13 & 14) are avid Prismz users.
  • Older teens are significantly less likely to engage with Prismz.

Additional Information
  • This demographic gains knowledge of games mostly through word of mouth and TV marketing campaigns.
  • The most common types of games this demographic downloads are free to play.
  • Which games children play is highly dictated by their parents. Free-to-play games are so popular with children because they do not need to ask for approval from their parents.
  • This demographic feels no connection and has very little experience with Empire Builders.
  • This demographic gains knowledge of games generally through word of mouth and influencers, and particularly through digital campaigns. The most common types of games this demographic downloads are free-to-play or one-time purchases in an app store.
  • Teens are incredibly avid phone-game players. They were the earliest adopters when it came to augmented reality, and they were the drivers behind the success of games such as PikimenGo!
  • This demographic has little experience with Empire Builders. Teens have an affinity for novelty; tying this game to an older franchise diminishes its excitement.
  • This demographic gains knowledge of games generally through word of mouth and influencers, and particularly through digital campaigns. The most common types of games this demographic downloads are free-to-play or one-time purchases in an app store.
  • Young adults are slower to adopt new games than children and teens are, but they are 'stickier' in that they remain players for longer than the younger players do. This population is also the most willing to participate in microtransactions in-game.
  • This demographic feels a strong connection with Empire Builders. However, there is still a desire for novelty and casualness that seems to be threatened by the game being 'very connected' to the Empire Builders universe.
  • This demographic gains knowledge of games predominantly through their children and TV campaigns. Parents dictate the consumption behavior of their children. They themselves are unlikely to play the games. Parents have a strong aversion to in-game microtransactions. More particularly, they worry that games might fool their children into spending money needlessly.
  • There has been controversy in the news lately surrounding the 'pay to win' business model some game developers implement. These are games that incentivize players to make in-game purchases that make advancement quicker or that enhance the fun. Children are particularly targeted and are often tricked into making these purchases. Hence, parents have very negative reactions to such games.
